sub_niche: Home Gardening, Plant Care & Outdoor Spaces

archetype.archetype_expression: The experienced gardener next door who shares wisdom earned through seasons of trial and error. Gets dirt under their nails and genuinely celebrates when your tomatoes finally ripen. Patient teacher who knows gardening is a journey, not a destination. Never makes you feel bad about failed plants—everyone has them.

soul.one_sentence: Growing confidence alongside your garden—real advice from real gardeners.
soul.expanded: Gardening isn't about Pinterest-perfect plots—it's about the joy of growing things, learning from failures, and connecting with nature. We're here with practical guidance, honest about what works and what doesn't, celebrating every gardener from apartment balconies to sprawling backyards. Your first successful tomato matters as much as a prize-winning rose.
soul.what_we_are: Practical gardening education from experienced growers. Honest about challenges. Celebrating all garden sizes. Real results over perfect aesthetics. Zone-aware advice. Season-specific guidance.
soul.what_we_are_not: Not intimidating garden perfection. Not assuming everyone has acres. Not ignoring climate differences. Not making gardening seem harder than it is. Not gatekeeping 'real' gardening.

if_this_site_were.person: A 52-year-old gardener who learned from their grandmother and has been growing things for decades. Equally excited about a first-time gardener's single tomato plant and a master gardener's heirloom collection. Always has plant starts to share and advice given without judgment. Wears well-loved gardening gloves and has dirt permanently under their nails.
if_this_site_were.place: A well-tended but not perfectly manicured garden. Productive raised beds, some cheerful chaos, evidence of experiments both successful and failed. A potting bench with well-worn tools. Morning coffee in the garden. Real and lived-in, not staged for photos.
if_this_site_were.time_of_day: Early morning—the best time to be in the garden, dew on leaves, birds singing, cool air before the day heats up.
if_this_site_were.season: Late spring—everything growing, possibilities everywhere, planting season energy, that magical moment when the garden really comes alive.
if_this_site_were.sound: Birds singing, gentle breeze through leaves, distant bees humming, quiet morning peace, maybe a wind chime.
if_this_site_were.texture: Rich soil between fingers, smooth leaves, rough bark, cool morning air, the satisfying weight of a ripe tomato.
if_this_site_were.smell: Fresh earth after watering, blooming flowers, morning grass, tomato plant leaves (that distinctive green smell), herbs releasing fragrance.
if_this_site_were.taste: Sun-warmed tomato straight from the vine, fresh herbs pinched while walking past, garden-to-table satisfaction.
if_this_site_were.temperature: Cool morning warming up—perfect gardening weather, comfortable for work, plants happy.
if_this_site_were.weather: Clear morning after rain—plants happy, soil workable, perfect conditions.
if_this_site_were.music_genre: Quiet acoustic or birdsong—nothing competing with garden sounds, maybe gentle folk music.
if_this_site_were.movie: A documentary about community gardens or regenerative farming—hopeful, practical, connecting people to earth.
if_this_site_were.book: A well-worn gardening guide with notes in margins and dirt on pages, passed down through generations.

primary_persona.name: Beginning Bonnie
primary_persona.description: Someone who wants to grow things but isn't sure where to start. Maybe has a balcony, small yard, or is renting and wants container gardens. Intimidated by gardening complexity but motivated by fresh food, beauty, stress relief, or wanting to connect with nature.
primary_persona.mindset: Eager but uncertain. Doesn't want to fail. Wants clear guidance without overwhelming information. Believes they might not have a 'green thumb' but wants to try.
pain_points: Don't know what's worth the effort
Feel like they lack natural ability
objections: I kill every plant I touch
I don't have a green thumb

secondary_persona.name: Expanding Emma
secondary_persona.description: Already gardening successfully with basics, wants to expand skills—maybe vegetable gardening, perennials, specific challenges like shade gardens or native plants. Looking for next-level guidance.
secondary_persona.how_they_differ: Needs depth over basics, specific problem-solving, expansion ideas, more advanced techniques, seasonal planning

tertiary_persona.name: Design-focused Dana
tertiary_persona.description: Interested in outdoor spaces as living areas—landscaping, garden design, outdoor living spaces. Aesthetics alongside function. Wants their garden to be beautiful as well as productive.
tertiary_persona.how_they_differ: Needs design guidance, outdoor living content, aesthetics focus, landscape planning, curb appeal

anti_persona.description: Perfectionists who shame imperfect gardens. Those who gatekeep 'real' gardening. People only interested in expensive landscaping without actual growing. Those who judge others' garden choices.
anti_persona.why_not: All gardens valid. No shaming imperfection. Growing matters more than aesthetics. Every space counts.
